contents.title: ## Introduction
contents.text:
This report summarizes the results of public input, encompassing:
 * __607 statements__
 * __225,040 votes__
 * 11 topics
 * 73 subtopics

All voters were anonymous.

contents.title: ## Overview
contents.text:
Below is a high level overview of the topics discussed in the conversation, as well as the percentage of statements categorized under each topic. Note that the percentages may add up to greater than 100% when statements fall under more than one topic.

*   **Transportation (18%):** The conversation on transportation highlighted statements calling for improved traffic flow through control system adjustments and solutions for railroad obstructions, alongside roadway enhancements via widening and new construction. Statements also urged expanded pedestrian and bicycle infrastructure, more comprehensive public transit, increased parking in key areas, and consideration of airport improvements.
*   **Community Services (13%):** The conversation on community services centered on statements addressing affordable housing and homelessness with diverse strategies and support systems. Statements also emphasized enhancing community well-being through expanded recreation, parks, community centers, and programs for various age groups, alongside bolstering food security and targeted assistance for underserved populations.
*   **Economic Development (12%):** The conversation on economic development focused on statements advocating for a vibrant local economy by attracting and retaining diverse businesses, especially those offering higher wages and supporting local entrepreneurship. Statements also emphasized improving workforce conditions through fair compensation and worker protections, while exploring strategies like commercial area revitalization and tourism enhancement.
*   **Education (12%):** The conversation on education included statements about enhancing curriculum content with practical skills, comprehensive health and safety education, and robust arts programs across K-12 and higher education. Statements also examined financial frameworks, educational structures, access, and student well-being, including nutrition and safety measures.
*   **Quality of Life (12%):** The conversation on quality of life featured statements on fostering an inclusive and equitable community, addressing fairness, diversity, and support for various groups. Statements also expressed desires for improvements to the physical environment, including beautification, maintenance, parks, recreation, and housing, alongside a vibrant cultural scene and accessible entertainment.
*   **Public Safety (10%):** The conversation on public safety included statements raising concerns about traffic violations, drug-related issues, specific crimes, and emergency response adequacy. Statements explored enhancements in policing and enforcement, debated systemic approaches for offenders, and highlighted the need for adequate resources, training, new regulations, and improved community safety measures.
*   **Government Administration (8%):** The conversation on Government Administration examined statements on financial management, including tax fairness, spending efficiency, and new revenue streams. Statements also centered on ethical obligations of public officials, calling for accountability and transparency, while exploring structural reforms and increased citizen influence.
*   **Healthcare (5%):** The conversation on healthcare included statements highlighting concerns about local healthcare infrastructure and market practices, alongside the need to improve access to medical, mental health, and reproductive care. Statements also explored health-oriented solutions for drug addiction and addressed preventative measures like comprehensive sexual education.
*   **Land Use and Zoning (5%):** The conversation on land use and zoning revealed statements concerning development density, its impact on neighborhood character, and farmland preservation. Statements advocated for urban planning with mixed-use developments, enhanced walkability, improved property maintenance, and reforms to planning processes for greater community involvement.
*   **Environment (5%):** The conversation on the environment included statements emphasizing the need to enhance recycling services, reduce litter through increased public waste bins and stricter enforcement, and promote broader sustainability initiatives. Statements also advocated for expanding and preserving green spaces and increasing the tree canopy.
*   **Infrastructure (5%):** The conversation on infrastructure focused on statements calling for enhanced internet services through expanded fiber networks, increased provider competition, and municipal options. Statements also emphasized improved roadways, pedestrian infrastructure, better water runoff management, street lighting, and the expansion of essential utilities.

contents.title: ## Top 5 Most Discussed Subtopics
contents.text: 73 subtopics of discussion emerged. These 5 subtopics had the most statements submitted.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Optimize traffic signal operations.
* Reduce overall traffic congestion.
* Improve intersection design/safety.
* Improve driver behavior and safety.
* Address train crossing disruptions.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Widen roads to increase capacity.
* Reduce traffic congestion and improve flow.
* Build new roads and connections.
* Improve road quality, design, and safety.
* Better manage road construction.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Sidewalk expansion and quality
* Bike infrastructure development
* Path network connectivity
* Pedestrian-focused public spaces
* Safe and multi-functional paths

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Government responsibility for homelessness.
* Housing options and support services.
* Funding homeless aid and housing.
* Prioritizing homeless students and families.
* Addressing rental costs and affordability.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* More diverse recreational facilities needed
* Develop riverfront for recreation
* Expand programming for all ages
* More indoor recreation options desired
* Improve funding and facility access

contents.title: ## Topics
contents.text: From the statements submitted, 11 high level topics were identified, as well as 73 subtopics. Based on voting patterns both points of common ground as well as differences of opinion have been identified and are described below.

subContents.title: ### Transportation (109 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 6 subtopics, comprising a total of 109 statements.

subContents.title: #### Traffic Flow (37 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Desire for Improved Traffic Flow and Identification of Problem Areas**: Many statements express a need to improve traffic flow generally and identify specific roads or intersections, such as Scottsville Road and Fairview Avenue, as being particularly problematic.
*   **Proposed Modifications to Traffic Control Systems**: Statements offer suggestions for managing traffic, including adjusting stoplight timing, adding or removing traffic lights, implementing roundabouts, and creating dedicated turn lanes or restricting left turns.
*   **Issues and Solutions Related to Railroad Crossings**: Several statements highlight problems with trains obstructing traffic and suggest remedies like grade separations, such as overpasses or underpasses, or improved warning mechanisms.
*   **Concerns Regarding Driver Conduct and Road Safety**: Some statements point to problematic driver behaviors, such as running red lights or failing to stop, and suggest a need for better driver education or an emphasis on safety over vehicle speed, while others mention issues with slow drivers.
*   **Questioning the Prioritization of Traffic Issues**: A statement expresses the view that traffic and vehicle dependency should not be a primary concern for the city.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants highlighted widespread traffic flow problems in Bowling Green, specifically citing congestion on Scottsville Road, Fairview Avenue, and Cemetery Road during rush hours. They proposed several actions, including studying traffic flow, correctly timing stoplights, budgeting to fix dangerous access roads off Scottsville Road, and adding turn lanes or restricting left turns on busy roads like the bypass. Additionally, participants requested the installation of elevating arms at all railroad crossings and suggested that driver education include turnabout rules. Participants also pointed to problematic driver behaviors, such as running red lights and failing to stop at stop signs, as contributing to traffic issues.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While participants broadly supported addressing traffic congestion on roads like Scottsville Road and correctly timing stoplights, opinions differed regarding one participant's view that Scottsville Road, among other areas, had too many traffic lights.

subContents.title: #### Roadways (27 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Desire for Road Widening and Increased Capacity**: Numerous statements call for widening existing roads, intersections, and access ways to improve traffic capacity and ease movement.
*   **Calls for New Road Construction and Enhanced Connectivity**: Several statements propose the building of new roads, bypasses, interchanges, or connections to expand the road network and provide alternative routes.
*   **Concerns Regarding Traffic Congestion and Operational Issues**: Statements express frustration with traffic congestion, delays from road work or closures, and suggest improvements to traffic flow, such as changes to street directionality or the design of service roads.
*   **Emphasis on Roadway Design, Maintenance Standards, and Safety Features**: Some statements focus on specific roadway design elements like turn lanes or medians, the quality of road surfaces and maintenance, and safety considerations including visibility, signage, and potential hazards.
*   **Proposals for Specific Project Completion, Funding, and Ancillary Infrastructure**: A few statements address the need to complete specific ongoing projects, suggest how new developments could contribute to road funding, or request additional roadway-related infrastructure such as EV charging stations.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants identified several road improvement needs, proposing that new developments help fund road widening in areas where these developments increase traffic. They requested leveling manhole covers during resurfacing and improving road visibility with reflectors and better signage. Participants also called for specific road widenings: parts of the Bypass; Nashville Road between the roundabout and Campbell Lane to alleviate 5 o'clock congestion and past Chaney’s & Buchanan Park due to its dangerous conditions, especially for a school area; Smallhouse Road at Campbell Lane to accommodate three lanes; and Scottsville Road to four or more lanes between I-65 and Lovers Lane, with one participant suggesting the removal of its service road. Furthermore, a participant advocated for improving the Bypass to serve as a genuine city bypass.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While participants broadly supported various road improvements and specific road widenings, opinions differed regarding the general scale of road construction and other road-related concerns. One statement called for building more roads generally due to traffic conditions. Another statement identified animated digital business signs as a road hazard that distracts drivers. A further statement proposed widening additional specific routes, including Cemetery Road, Russellville Road, Lover’s Lane, Campbell Lane, The Old ByPass, and a segment of Scottsville Road.

subContents.title: #### Pedestrian Infrastructure (21 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Demand for Sidewalk Expansion and Improvement**: Several statements call for building new sidewalks in specific locations and improving existing ones, while some also address the prioritization of these efforts and the suitability of sidewalk placement.
*   **Need for Enhanced Connectivity**: Multiple statements express a desire for better connections between existing sidewalks, bike paths, and trails to create a more cohesive and usable network.
*   **Call for More and Safer Bicycle Infrastructure**: A number of statements advocate for increased and improved infrastructure for cyclists, including more bike lanes, trails, and features to ensure rider safety.
*   **Interest in Pedestrian-Priority Areas and Multi-Use Paths**: Some statements suggest creating pedestrian-only zones, enhancing the walking experience with amenities, and designing wider sidewalks for multiple uses like walking, biking, and skateboarding.
*   **Concerns Regarding Sidewalk Management and Utility**: Certain statements raise issues about the current management of sidewalk projects, such as repetitive work, installation in unsuitable locations, and the problem of sidewalks being obstructed by parked vehicles.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants call for enhanced pedestrian and cyclist infrastructure, highlighting the current disconnected nature of sidewalks and bicycle paths. They propose specific actions such as developing the Greenway into a continuous trail reaching major city parts including the square, WKU, and GM, and installing new sidewalks along major roads like Three Springs, Scottsville Road, and Campbell Lane. Furthermore, participants request wider bike lanes for safety from cars, future sidewalks designed for multi-use, and amenities like plants and benches to create a city that prioritizes enjoyable and safe walking and biking for both transport and recreation.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While there was broad support for enhanced pedestrian infrastructure, opinions differed with respect to the proposal by some participants to create pedestrian-only streets.

subContents.title: #### Public Transportation (10 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Desire for Enhanced and Expanded Public Transportation Services**: Several statements express a need for more robust public transportation, including calls for a "real bus system," expanded service areas, and generally "more public transportation options."
* **Emphasis on Accessibility and Meeting Diverse User Needs**: Multiple statements highlight the importance of public transit being accessible and catering to specific groups such as seniors, individuals with disabilities, those with limited driving capabilities, and people needing transport for work, with mentions of wheelchair accessibility.
* **Exploration of Varied Transit Modes and Inter-City Connectivity**: Some statements suggest specific alternative transit modes like train service, an unmanned trolley system, and dedicated commuting services, particularly a connection to Nashville.
* **Call for Operational Improvements to Transit Services**: Statements identify needs for operational enhancements such as 24/7 service, increased stop frequency in residential areas, and ensuring systems are clean, efficient, and easy to enter/exit.
* **Consideration of Funding and Innovative Solutions**: The statements include mentions of requiring funding and support for existing bus services, alongside encouragement for creative and technologically advanced approaches like solar-powered or unmanned systems.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed providing accessible transportation for seniors who have difficulty driving and suggested that a clean, efficient public transportation system would significantly help individuals with limited ability or desire to drive.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Parking (10 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Downtown Parking Needs**: Statements express a desire for increased or improved parking in downtown areas, particularly around Fountain Square, to support businesses and attract visitors, with some suggesting changes to reserved space policies.
*   **WKU-Related Parking Concerns**: Issues regarding parking accessibility on the WKU campus for students and visitors are raised, alongside the impact of university-related parking on adjacent residential areas, leading to suggestions for permits or new campus parking structures.
*   **Proposals for Parking Structures**: The construction of parking garages or dedicated parking structures is advocated in multiple statements as a solution to parking shortages in both downtown and WKU campus locations.
*   **Emphasis on Parking Accessibility and Availability**: Several statements highlight the importance of making parking more accessible and readily available for various users, including businesses, students, and visitors, and suggest better management of existing parking like reserved spaces.
*   **Parking in Urban Development Context**: Some statements connect parking development with broader urban planning goals, such as creating pedestrian zones, integrating green spaces with parking facilities, or designing parking to improve traffic flow.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants identified several parking improvement needs. For downtown, they proposed retaining accessible parking for existing businesses during redevelopment, increasing overall parking by making reserved spaces available in the evening, and improving parking around the square to attract college students. Participants also requested more accessible parking on the WKU campus for students and visitors. Additionally, one participant suggested connecting business parking lots to reduce unnecessary traffic on main roadways.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Airport (6 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Airport Relocation**: Some statements propose relocating the airport, with suggestions including moving it outside city limits, to the transpark, or due to concerns about current land valuation.
* **Flight Services**: One statement expresses a desire for the airport to offer better flight options and more destinations, noting a comparison with another airport's services.
* **On-Site Pedestrian Safety**: One statement identifies a need for a footbridge near the airport to address safety concerns for pedestrians crossing a road.
* **Access to Alternative Airports**: One statement suggests providing regular and affordable daily transportation from Bowling Green to Nashville Airport.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: A participant suggests providing regular and affordable daily transport to Nashville Airport from Bowling Green.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: ### Community Services (76 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 6 subtopics, comprising a total of 76 statements.

subContents.title: #### Affordable Housing and Homelessness (21 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Varied Perspectives on Responsibility for Addressing Homelessness**: Statements present differing views on whether government, non-profit organizations, employers, or a collaborative approach should be primarily responsible for tackling homelessness.
*   **Diverse Proposed Solutions Including Housing Types, Support Services, and Policy Changes**: A range of solutions are proposed in the statements, encompassing various housing models such as tiny homes and apartments, with differing opinions on their suitability, alongside support services like rehabilitation, job readiness, financial assistance, and changes to rental policies.
*   **Funding Initiatives Through Proposed Tax Increases**: Several statements advocate for funding homelessness initiatives, particularly for students and families, through specific increases in occupational taxes.
*   **Specific Focus on Homeless Students and Families**: A notable number of statements emphasize the issue of homelessness among K-12 students and their families, calling for targeted housing and support for this demographic.
*   **Concerns About Public Space Usage, Homeless Population Growth, and Rental Market Conditions**: Some statements express concerns regarding the presence of homeless individuals in public facilities like libraries and the perceived growth of the homeless population, while others highlight the unaffordability of local rental housing as a key issue.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants discussed homelessness in Bowling Green, with one proposing a "Clean Slate" program, similar to Ft Worth's, enabling homeless individuals to earn money by cleaning the city. Another participant suggested collaboration between local government, for-profit, and non-profit entities to address housing and economic equality. Participants also requested various forms of aid, such as temporary housing, tiny house parks, health clinics, rehabilitation services, and job readiness resources, and called for officials to ensure shelter options, especially for families, while noting the need for better methods to curtail and rehabilitate the growing homeless population.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Parks and Recreation (20 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Requests for New and Enhanced Recreational Infrastructure**: Numerous statements call for the creation of new recreational facilities such as sports complexes, an ice rink, and various swimming options, or the enhancement of existing ones.
* **Emphasis on Riverfront and Downtown Area Development**: Several statements advocate for developing the riverfront and downtown areas with features like river walks, parks, and event spaces to foster community engagement and recreation.
* **Demand for Expanded Programming and Specific Activities**: There is a stated desire for more recreational programming, especially for adults, seniors, and families, including suggestions for specific activities like pickleball and unique park concepts.
* **Concerns About Facility Access, Equity, and Affordability**: Some statements express concerns regarding the limited availability of certain public facilities, inequitable access to resources like gyms, and the financial cost associated with using recreational amenities.
* **Discussion on Park Philosophy, Funding, and Priorities**: Statements present varied perspectives on the current number and type of parks, the need for increased city funding for parks, and how park development should be prioritized against other community issues.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed developing the downtown and Barren River waterfront with amenities such as a river walk, parks, restaurants, and water features for canoeing and kayaking, aiming to provide entertainment, recreation, and community gathering spaces. They also requested an increase in family-friendly activities, the establishment of year-round public adult swim facilities, suggesting making the Lovers Lane Complex available, and more programming for adults and seniors through city and county parks. Furthermore, participants advocated for more green spaces, expressing concern that existing parks have become sports complexes, and suggested creating more outdoor public swimming options, especially for summer.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While participants broadly supported developing more green spaces and outdoor recreational amenities, opinions differed on the adequacy of existing parks and the specific types of new facilities required. Some statements advocated for specialized indoor and outdoor sports complexes, including indoor soccer fields for youth and an ice rink. Another statement questioned the need for additional parks, suggesting a focus on addressing homelessness in public spaces like libraries first.

subContents.title: #### Community Centers and Youth Programs (16 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Focus on Youth and Family Activities and Venues**: Several statements express a need for more diverse programs, activities, and dedicated spaces for children, teenagers, and families, including mentorship, after-school options with extended hours, children's museums, and play arenas.
*   **Desire for Increased Community Engagement and Events**: Statements indicate a wish for more opportunities that foster community connection and shared experiences, such as neighborhood interactions, local festivals, downtown programs, and improvements to existing community traditions.
*   **Call for Specific Community Resources and Adult Enrichment**: Multiple statements identify needs for particular public amenities like public Wi-Fi and additional library branches, resources for organizations such as free meeting spaces for nonprofits, and community enrichment classes for adult hobbyists.
*   **Emphasis on Stronger University-Community Collaboration**: Some statements suggest a desire for increased cooperation between local universities, particularly WKU, and the broader community, encompassing shared resources, internships, and community involvement initiatives.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed several enhancements for Bowling Green, including increased cooperation between WKU and the city for internships and community involvement, and the introduction of community enrichment classes for hobbyists, such as woodworking and gardening. Additionally, participants suggested implementing free WIFI around Fountain Square, organizing more summer weekend festivals, and establishing a children's or science museum to cater to young children.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Support for Underserved Populations (10 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Housing and Neighborhood Improvement**: Several statements propose initiatives such as home improvement grants, collaborative housing efforts, and allocating beautification funds to enhance living conditions in low-income or older areas.
*   **Economic Considerations and Financial Relief**: Some statements address the importance of economic equality, the financial burden of service fees, and the fiscal impact associated with population changes and social services.
*   **Targeted Support Programs and Needs Assessment**: Multiple statements advocate for specific programs like arts and sciences for youth and comprehensive rehabilitation for individuals on probation, alongside directly consulting low-income or disabled residents to understand their needs.
*   **Differing Views on Immigration**: The statements present contrasting perspectives on immigration, with one highlighting perceived cost savings from lower immigration and another calling for resources to support the integration of immigrants and refugees.
*   **Community Collaboration and Resource Accessibility**: Some statements emphasize the need for partnerships between various entities to address social issues and for institutions to make facilities and resources more accessible to the broader community, including those in need.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed several community improvements, including asking low-income or disabled residents about their needs and allocating beautification money to low-income areas rather than to wealthy areas. They also suggested that local government, for-profit entities, and non-profit organizations should collaborate on housing and economic equality. Furthermore, participants called for comprehensive probation rehabilitation programs that include addiction treatment, life and job skills, and assistance with securing housing and employment, and proposed revitalizing older parts of Bowling Green by providing home improvement grants to homeowners, subject to an approval process.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Food Security (8 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Focus on Preventing Child Hunger**: Several statements highlight the imperative to prevent child hunger, suggesting official responsibility and the establishment of adequate summer feeding programs in public schools.
* **Improving Access to Food Retail and Payment Methods**: Some statements call for better physical access to grocery stores in specific areas and for university students, as well as for major retailers to accept EBT for grocery pick-up, especially for the elderly and disabled.
* **Expanding Food Assistance Program Scope**: Multiple statements propose broadening food assistance programs by suggesting new aid for college students who may not qualify for existing support and by advocating for the extension of SNAP grant availability for neighborhood improvements to the entire county.
* **Promotion of Fresh Food Availability and Local Agriculture**: Certain statements advocate for increasing access to fresh food through the development of new grocery stores and the expansion of community farming programs.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants propose that all public schools should implement adequate summer feeding programs to ensure no child goes hungry. One participant specifically calls upon officials in Bowling Green / Warren County to take responsibility for preventing child hunger in their community.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Senior Services (6 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Recreational and Social Engagement**: Some statements call for expanded recreational programming and support for specific activities for seniors, often through city and county parks departments.
*   **Specific Housing Needs**: Certain statements express a desire for particular types of senior living options, such as communities designed for a younger (50+) demographic or upscale apartments for those 55 and older.
*   **Affordable and Accessible Supports**: Some statements emphasize the necessity for affordable supports for the elderly and aging population, including making essential services like grocery pick-up more accessible through EBT.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants highlighted the community's need for affordable supports targeting the elderly and aging population. Furthermore, participants suggested that city and county parks departments increase programming options for adults and seniors.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: ### Economic Development (75 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 8 subtopics, comprising a total of 75 statements.

subContents.title: #### Consumer Needs and Retail Diversity (15 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Demand for a Wider Variety of Retail and Dining Options**: Statements frequently express desires for specific new businesses, including various types of grocery stores, named restaurant chains, pet stores, an expanded farmer's market, and unique local shops, to broaden consumer choices.
*   **Concerns Over Grocery Store Quality and Competition**: Several statements highlight dissatisfaction with current grocery offerings, particularly regarding produce quality, and call for increased competition through the introduction of new grocers like Publix.
*   **Retail Location and Accessibility Considerations**: Statements address the geographic placement of businesses, advocating for more retail in the downtown area, improved access in low-income neighborhoods, and a broader distribution of shopping options to reduce traffic and prevent out-of-town trips.
*   **Preference for Local Character and Unique Businesses**: Some statements emphasize the need for more independent businesses that contribute to the town's distinct character, sometimes contrasting them with existing chain establishments.
*   **Divergent Views on Restaurant Needs and Mall Revitalization**: While some statements call for specific new restaurants, another suggests the current number of restaurants is adequate, and a separate statement proposes remodeling the Greenwood Mall to enhance its appeal to shoppers.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants propose attracting businesses like Costco and Trader Joe's to Bowling Green to prevent residents from shopping in Nashville. Participants also request more retail businesses instead of offices in the downtown district, specifically around Fountain Square. Furthermore, participants advocate for more unique local businesses, such as White Squirrel and Nats, to add character, rather than chain establishments like Olive Garden and Belks.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Fair Wages and Benefits (13 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Calls for Increased Minimum Wage**: Several statements advocate for raising the minimum wage, with some specifying amounts like $15 per hour or tying it to a living wage.
* **Regulation of Temporary Employment Agencies**: Some statements express concerns about temporary employment practices and call for measures such as increased pay transparency for employees, higher wages for temporary workers to account for reduced economic security, and provision of benefits like FMLA equivalents.
* **Enhancement of Worker Rights and Protections**: Certain statements propose strengthening worker protections by barring non-compete agreements and ensuring the right for workers to assemble and bargain collectively for improved pay, benefits, and working conditions.
* **Connection Between Wages, Job Market, and Living Costs**: A few statements address the need for higher-paying jobs with opportunities for advancement, suggest that employers should increase wages and improve working conditions to fill openings, and observe that current wages are not keeping pace with the cost of living.
* **Conditional Business Incentives**: Some statements suggest that eligibility for business tax credits or other incentives should be contingent upon employers meeting specified minimum wage and benefit standards, such as a minimum hourly wage plus benefits.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants called for higher-paying jobs in BG, suggesting actions such as incentivizing their arrival to address the issue of the cost of living outpacing wages. They also proposed that companies struggling to fill job openings should raise wages and improve working conditions, and one participant highlighted the importance of opportunities for career advancement with reasonable raises.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While participants broadly supported companies raising wages, opinions differed with respect to implementing a minimum wage increase; one statement called for a higher minimum wage, and another proposed a specific rate of $15 per hour.

subContents.title: #### Workforce Development (9 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Magnitude of Open Job Positions**: One statement emphasizes that a large number of open jobs in Warren County constitutes a significant workforce development problem.
*   **Strategies to Address Unfilled Job Openings**: Several statements suggest actions for local companies and the Workforce Development Board to fill job openings, including providing transportation, improving wages and working conditions, and recruiting from areas with high unemployment.
*   **Availability of Job Seeker Support**: Some statements mention job training programs targeted at lower-income individuals and identify specific career centers as resources for employment.
*   **Obstacles to Securing Employment**: A statement highlights how past DUI records can prevent individuals from being hired at large local employers, viewing this as an undue penalty.
*   **Perspectives on Job Availability and Workforce Board Transparency**: Statements present views on the ease of finding employment in Warren County and include a call for the Workforce Development Board to publish data on its job placement efforts.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants identified workforce development as a significant issue, with one participant citing over 6500 open jobs in Warren County. To address this, participants proposed job training programs for lower-income individuals and suggested that companies unable to fill positions should raise wages and improve working conditions.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Downtown Revitalization (9 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Geographic Expansion and Project Completion**: Some statements call for expanding downtown development towards the river and other specific areas, as well as completing current projects.
*   **Focus on Rehabilitation and Reuse**: A number of statements advocate for prioritizing the rehabilitation and reuse of existing buildings and renovating current businesses over new construction.
*   **Desired Business Mix and Service Enhancements**: Various statements identify desires for specific business types, such as discount grocers and more retail over offices, and enhancements to existing services like restaurants.
*   **Support for Business Sustainability**: One statement points to a need for better support for downtown tenants to improve business longevity and address turnover.
*   **Marketing and Regional Attraction**: Certain statements propose developing marketing campaigns and leveraging features like the riverfront to attract visitors from surrounding areas and tourists.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants offered proposals for downtown development, with some advocating for prioritizing the rehabilitation and reuse of existing buildings, including renovating rundown businesses and storefronts, instead of new construction. Another participant suggested extending downtown development to the river, noting that tourists frequently seek out parks and restaurants near water.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Tourism (8 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Strategies for Tourism Promotion**: Statements discuss various approaches to marketing, including targeted advertising campaigns and the use of signage, with one statement expressing concern about over-reliance on signage for promotion.
*   **Enhancement and Diversification of Local Attractions**: Suggestions are made for developing new attractions like riverfront areas and for better promoting existing diverse offerings such as local food, small farms, and activities beyond singular prominent features.
*   **Introduction of New Tourism Concepts**: One statement proposes considering recreational cannabis as a novel avenue for attracting tourists and generating economic benefits.
*   **Mechanisms for Increasing Visitor Engagement**: A specific idea presented is the creation of a "Tourism Passport" to incentivize visits to multiple establishments through discounts.
*   **Assessment of Current Tourism Initiatives**: A concern is raised in one statement that existing tourism efforts are insufficient for the area.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed enhancing local tourism by extending downtown development to the river, leveraging tourists' interest in waterside parks and restaurants. They also identified local food and small farms as significant attractions for Bowling Green. Furthermore, participants suggested that Warren County should broaden its tourism promotion beyond Corvettes to include its other diverse offerings, noting that current tourism efforts in Warren County are insufficient.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While participants broadly supported strategies for enhancing local tourism and broadening its promotion, opinions differed with respect to the proposal from some participants that legalizing recreational cannabis in Kentucky could also contribute to these tourism goals, in addition to increasing revenue, creating job opportunities, and demonstrating regional leadership.

subContents.title: #### Business Attraction and Retention (6 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Emphasis on Higher-Paying Jobs and Talent Retention**: Some statements highlight the necessity of creating and incentivizing higher-paying jobs to retain local talent, particularly college graduates, and to address the increasing cost of living.
*   **Targeted Geographic Development for Businesses**: Several statements call for the development of specific areas, such as the Louisville Rd area and the bypass area, with new businesses and attractive structures.
*   **Social Ordinances as a Business Attraction Factor**: One statement proposes that enacting a fairness ordinance would enhance Bowling Green's appeal to new businesses by reflecting a modern ethical environment.
*   **Concerns Regarding Regional Competitiveness for Professionals**: A statement expresses concern about Bowling Green's ability to compete with larger cities like Nashville and Louisville in attracting young professionals.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants suggest creating jobs to retain college-educated students who are leaving for better-paying jobs. They also propose developing the bypass area, which participants identify as neglected and losing business, by adding new businesses and attractive structures.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While participants broadly supported adding new businesses to develop local areas, opinions differed regarding whether implementing a fairness ordinance would attract new businesses by preventing the town from appearing ethically outdated.

subContents.title: #### Small Business Support (5 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Financial Support for Local Businesses**: Several statements advocate for providing financial aid, such as grants or incentives, to foster the development of local businesses.
*   **Preference for Local Ownership**: Multiple statements express a desire to support locally owned small businesses, with one statement specifying these should be prioritized over chain businesses and outside investors.
*   **Business Skills and Development Needs**: One statement identifies a lack of business skills as a challenge for local tenants, suggesting a need for better support in this area.
*   **Call for More Diverse Local Businesses**: Some statements articulate a desire for an increased quantity and variety of local establishments, including specific mentions of coffee shops, chefs, and brewers.
*   **Retaining Graduates Through Local Entrepreneurship**: One statement suggests using business development grants to encourage local university graduates to start businesses and remain in the community.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed instituting business development grants to foster local entrepreneurship in Bowling Green. One participant suggested these grants could encourage Western Kentucky University graduates to remain in the city by starting local businesses. Another participant advocated for grants and other measures to stimulate local business development, citing the example that Bowling Green, for its size, has essentially only one local coffee shop.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Other (19 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Economic Development Through Policy Changes**: Several statements propose policy changes, such as legalizing marijuana, hemp, expanding alcohol sales, or introducing casinos, as means to foster economic growth, generate revenue, and create jobs.
* **Housing Development, Affordability, and Equity**: Statements address housing through calls for collaboration on housing equality, increased affordable home ownership, mixed-use development in disadvantaged areas, and landlord incentives, while one statement voices concern about potential negative economic impacts from overbuilding apartments.
* **Business Competition and Market Regulation**: Multiple statements advocate for increased competition and governmental oversight in sectors like cable services and fuel, citing concerns about monopolies, price gouging, and the need for fair business practices.
* **Employment Practices and Worker Protection**: Some statements highlight a need to examine employer layoff practices and suggest measures, including potential laws, to provide greater protection for affected employees.
* **Urban Revitalization and Community Enhancement**: Statements suggest initiatives such as targeted revitalization of specific areas like the bypass and the adoption of fairness ordinances to improve the community's infrastructure, ethical standing, and overall attractiveness.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants expressed desires for increased competition for cable companies like Spectrum to address price gouging, with one suggesting rate regulation by local government. Another participant proposed collaboration between local government, for-profit entities, and non-profits to address housing and economic equality. A third participant called for a concerted effort, possibly a Tax Increment Financing (TIF) district, to revitalize the bypass area, which they identified as an eyesore. Additionally, participants requested the re-legalization of industrial hemp cultivation in Kentucky and advocated for Warren County to become fully "wet," arguing the current "moist" status hinders financial growth and tourism.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While participants supported re-legalizing industrial hemp cultivation in Kentucky, opinions differed regarding further economic and social measures. One set of statements proposed legalizing recreational cannabis or marijuana, citing potential benefits such as increased tourism, revenue, job creation, and regional leadership. Another statement suggested that a fairness ordinance in Bowling Green would attract new businesses.

subContents.title: ### Education (71 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 10 subtopics, comprising a total of 71 statements.

subContents.title: #### Curriculum And Instruction (18 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Curriculum Focus on Practical Skills and Future Preparedness**: Statements call for the curriculum to include more practical life skills, such as financial literacy, vocational training, and information about post-graduation options, alongside creative learning opportunities.
*   **Calls for Specific Subject Enhancements**: Several statements advocate for the improvement, mandatory inclusion, or increased comprehensiveness of specific subjects such as driver's education, sex education (including consent and STD prevention), and drug education.
*   **Language Education for Immigrant Students**: There are statements regarding language acquisition for immigrant and refugee students, with some suggesting dedicated support for learning English, culture, and laws, and others emphasizing a requirement for these students to learn and speak English.
*   **Discussion of Educational Standards and Quality**: Statements address the desired quality and consistency of education, with some advocating for a uniform minimum standard across schools and others aspiring for an education that surpasses basic state requirements.
*   **Adaptation of Instructional Approaches and Delivery**: Some statements suggest the adoption of varied teaching styles, like Montessori, to accommodate diverse learning needs and the consideration of alternative instructional delivery methods, such as remote learning for snow days.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed several educational enhancements for students. These included ensuring Warren County students receive the best available education, exceeding the Kentucky minimum, and educating high schoolers about their post-graduation options. Participants also suggested collaboration between all county and city schools to provide a uniform minimum level of education. Furthermore, specific curriculum proposals involved offering comprehensive, medically accurate sex education covering consent, safe sex practices, and STD prevention to combat teen pregnancy and STD rates, alongside a mandatory four-year high school life skills class teaching practical skills such as family finance, tax filing, car and home maintenance, cooking, sewing, and job application and interview techniques.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: Participants expressed differing opinions regarding English language acquisition for newcomers. One statement asserted that all immigrants should learn and speak English, while another specified a requirement for refugees to learn and speak English.

subContents.title: #### Higher Education (16 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Purpose of Higher Education**: Statements present varied perspectives on whether higher education's primary aim is job preparation, developing informed citizens, or providing courses based on student interest.
* **University Financial Management**: Statements discuss factors contributing to tuition increases and offer differing views on managing university budgets, including the financial implications of cutting major programs like sports.
* **University-Community Engagement**: Multiple statements advocate for stronger, mutually beneficial relationships between universities and their local communities, encompassing resource sharing, internships, and local economic development.
* **Curriculum and Program Development**: Statements call for updates to existing academic programs, expansion of programs to meet specific needs, and the introduction of new courses, including those for student well-being or diverse interests.
* **Expansion of Educational Access and Offerings**: Some statements propose broadening post-secondary educational opportunities through technical programs for non-high school graduates, specialized training, and the development of institutions like junior colleges with diverse curricula.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed enhancing the relationship between Western Kentucky University (WKU) and the Bowling Green community through increased cooperation on internships, community involvement, and the development of stronger mutually beneficial partnerships. They requested more technical education programs for non-high school graduates, post-secondary training programs for special education students, and better incorporation of university resources, such as the Kentucky Museum, into the community. Additionally, participants suggested instituting a business development grant to encourage WKU graduates to establish local businesses in Bowling Green and advocated for WKU and local community colleges to continue offering courses based on student interest, regardless of their direct aid in job placement.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While there was broad support for WKU and local community colleges continuing to offer courses based on student interest regardless of their direct aid in job placement, opinions differed regarding the primary purpose of higher education. One statement asserted that job training is its main purpose. Another statement proposed that cutting a major sports program would be the best way for WKU to deal with budget cuts without harming academics.

subContents.title: #### School Funding (14 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Budget Management and Prioritization Within Educational Institutions**: Statements discuss how educational institutions should manage their finances, including making budget cuts, the debate over cutting specific programs and considering their revenue implications, and the need for better budgeting or prioritization of spending towards academics or youth programs.
*   **Impact of Different Funding Models and External Financial Pressures**: Several statements address how various funding approaches, such as the allocation of public money to private or charter schools, the erosion of the local tax base due to property development, or broader economic issues like pension crises, affect school funding.
*   **Concerns Regarding School Taxation and Governance of Funding**: Some statements express views on the level of school taxes, the impact of the tax base composition on school revenue, and the authority of officials, particularly unelected ones, in creating or increasing these taxes.
*   **Advocacy for Investment in Youth and Specific Educational Programs**: A number of statements call for increased financial support for youth generally or for particular educational areas, such as arts education and community after-school programs, sometimes contrasting this with other public spending.
*   **Accountability and Responsibility in School Finance**: Certain statements raise issues concerning who bears responsibility for financial challenges in education, such as university management versus government funding decisions, and call for accountability in funding acquisition practices or the operation of alternatively funded schools like charters.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants advocated for increased investment in youth, with one participant emphasizing that Community Education's after-school care, vital for working parents, should retain its funding. Another participant requested more public school funding for art education programs such as music, theater, and visual arts, while a different participant proposed reallocating $800,000 from a planned fountain in Lamkin Park to youth educational programs.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: Participants held differing opinions on one participant's proposal that WKU should cut a major sports program as the optimal strategy for addressing budget cuts while safeguarding academic quality.

subContents.title: #### School Choice (8 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Financial Implications for Public Schools**: Statements express concerns that directing public funds to private or charter schools could negatively affect public school finances, though one statement proposes accountability for charter schools as a way to address this potential financial burden.
*   **Desire for Increased Parental Choice and Equitable Access**: Several statements advocate for expanding parents' ability to choose among various educational options, including non-public, private, charter, or different public school districts, and emphasize making these choices accessible to families of all income levels and diverse backgrounds.
*   **Emphasis on Diverse School Choice Models and Their Value**: The statements highlight various specific school choice models such as private schools (including Catholic schools), non-public schools, and charter schools (including arts-based ones), with some noting their perceived benefits or advocating for their support and accessibility.
*   **Accountability for Charter Schools as a Financial Safeguard**: One statement specifically conditions the financial impact of future charter schools on public funding by asserting the need for their accountability to local school boards.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: Statements regarding educational choice presented varied perspectives. One statement proposed that parents should be able to choose any public school district within Bowling Green/Warren County for their children. Another statement advocated for supporting non-public or public charter school options, emphasizing viability for families of all income levels. A further statement suggested that a private Catholic high school would benefit everyone.

subContents.title: #### Safety (6 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Driver Education and Licensing Age Concerns**: Statements call for more thorough and mandatory driver's education, with suggestions including improving current high school classes described as "pitiful" and raising the licensing age.
*   **Expansion of Water Safety Education**: There are proposals for providing water safety and swim lessons to all K-12 students and for schools to offer these lessons to non-swimming parents or guardians in a private setting.
*   **School Bullying and Administrative Response**: A statement expresses concern about the prevalence of bullying in schools and alleges that administrators are ignoring this issue.
*   **Monitoring of University Greek Life**: One statement suggests that Greek Life on WKU's campus should be monitored.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed monitoring Greek Life on WKU's campus and advocated for driver’s education to be more thorough and mandatory before 16-year-olds are permitted to drive home from the courthouse.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Nutrition (5 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **School Meal Quality and Sourcing**: Statements address improving the nutritional value of school meals by suggesting the removal of high-sugar items and the incorporation of more local produce.
*   **Dietary Inclusivity and Food Security**: Some statements call for schools to provide special diet options catering to cultural differences or dietary needs and to implement summer feeding programs to ensure children do not go hungry.
*   **Physical Activity for Obesity Prevention**: One statement advocates for daily physical activity in schools as a means to combat the childhood obesity crisis.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### School Districting (5 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Merger or Combination of School Districts**: Some statements advocate for merging or combining separate school systems, such as those for the city and county.
*   **Re-evaluation and Redistricting of School Boundaries**: Several statements call for re-evaluating existing school district lines or redistricting schools, with one statement aiming to more evenly distribute students.
*   **Socioeconomic Segregation Concerns**: One statement expresses concern that current city and county school districting practices may intentionally lead to socioeconomic segregation, thus reducing learning opportunities.
*   **Financial Efficiency Through Consolidation**: A statement posits that combining school districts could reduce taxpayer overheads by decreasing multi-administration waste.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: Participants expressed differing opinions on the proposal that the city and county school systems should merge.

subContents.title: #### Arts Education (5 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Value Of Arts Education**: Statements indicate that arts are considered an important educational component and can contribute to student development.
* **Access To Arts Education**: Multiple statements express a need for more arts education opportunities, including in specific communities and geographic regions.
* **Funding For Arts Education**: One statement specifically addresses the necessity of increased financial support from public school systems for programs like music, theater, and visual arts.
* **Specific Arts Education Contexts**: Statements mention distinct environments for arts education, such as arts-based charter schools and within the Housing Authority.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants assert the importance of arts education in K-12 schools and propose that schools in Warren County and surrounding areas make this education available. They also request that public school systems provide more funding for specific art education programs, such as music, theater, and visual arts.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Class Size (2 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Concerns Over Class Size and School Crowding**: Statements express a desire for smaller class sizes, with one suggesting specific numerical targets, and another highlights existing overcrowding in particular schools.
* **Responses to School Capacity Pressures and Programmatic Impacts**: Statements suggest building new schools to accommodate population growth and utilizing available teachers to manage class sizes, while one statement also points to a negative effect on a specific educational program due to these pressures.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Teacher Recruitment And Retention (2 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Class Size Limits**: One statement advocates for establishing rules to reduce the number of students per teacher, suggesting a maximum of 20 and an ideal of 15.
*   **Targeted Recruitment and Retention**: One statement proposes recruiting and retaining the "best" K-13 teachers, specifically identifying graduates from WKU as the target pool.
*   **Assertion of Teacher Availability**: One statement asserts that there are plenty of teachers looking for work.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: ### Quality of Life (70 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 9 subtopics, comprising a total of 70 statements.

subContents.title: #### Community Diversity and Inclusion (13 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Debate Surrounding a Proposed Fairness Ordinance**: Statements express diverse views on implementing a fairness ordinance, including arguments for protecting citizens' rights, opposition based on perceived sufficiency of existing laws or ideological grounds, and suggestions for specific provisions.
* **Positive Views on Immigrant and Refugee Communities**: Several statements describe immigrant and refugee populations as beneficial to the city and county, enriching the community, and express a welcoming sentiment.
* **Advocacy for LGBTQ+ Rights and Accommodations**: Some statements call for non-discrimination based on sexual orientation and the provision of specific facilities such as gender-neutral housing and bathrooms for the LGBTQ+ community.
* **Assertion of Institutional Racism**: One statement reports firsthand experience of institutional racism and suggests the need for a plan to address it.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: There was disagreement among participants regarding the comment's statement that Bowling Green needs a fairness ordinance to protect the rights of its citizens.

subContents.title: #### City Beautification and Maintenance (13 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Calls for Enhanced Beautification, Amenities, and Quality-of-Life Improvements**: Statements express a desire for various city enhancements, including beautification projects like riverfront development and floral planting, the addition of amenities such as park-like spaces and healthy restaurants, and general improvements aimed at attracting residents and industries.
*   **Emphasis on Noise Control and Ordinance Enforcement**: Some statements call for the enforcement of existing city noise ordinances, the enactment and enforcement of such ordinances in the county, and specific attention to noise issues related to university activities and downtown residences.
*   **Advocacy for Pedestrian-Focused Urban Planning**: A few statements advocate for city planning that prioritizes pedestrians over cars, aiming to make walking more enjoyable and safer.
*   **Concerns Regarding Property Maintenance Regulations and Individual Freedoms**: Some statements voice concerns about current spending on yard maintenance enforcement and assert a desire for greater individual freedom in how property owners maintain their yards and homes.
*   **Expectations of City Responsibility in Infrastructure Management and Property Restoration**: Statements indicate expectations for the city to manage infrastructure, such as reducing overhead utility clusters, and to restore private property to its original condition following city projects.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed several civic improvements. One participant stated the city should restore lawns to their original quality after municipal projects, while another requested the freedom to plant flowers in their own yards. Other participants advocated for broader beautification efforts to enhance the city's appeal, suggesting developments like new parks, libraries, and an improved riverfront, along with establishing boulevard-like roads with planted flowers and reducing overhead utility clusters. They also emphasized prioritizing pedestrian-friendly urban planning to make walking enjoyable and safe, and stated these collective changes would help attract new residents, young families, and industries.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Arts and Culture (10 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
*   **Desire for Increased and Varied Arts Offerings**: Several statements express a desire for an expansion of arts infrastructure and programming, including the creation of art districts, more community programs, additional concerts, new cultural institutions like museums, and public art installations.
*   **Calls for Programming to Reflect Community Diversity**: Some statements call for arts and cultural programming to be more inclusive by reflecting the community's diverse demographics, such as racial/ethnic diversity, and by appealing to younger audiences.
*   **Concerns Regarding Specific Arts Venues and Development Impacts**: Some statements voice concerns about aspects of arts development, such as the programming choices at a specific venue and the alteration of historic buildings.
*   **Acknowledgement of Arts' Positive Contributions**: Some statements acknowledge the enriching impact of arts and culture on the city and their potential to provide engaging experiences.
*   **Need for Enhanced Promotion of Cultural Activities**: One statement highlights a need for better publicizing of a broader array of cultural activities beyond currently prominent events.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants stated that the arts enrich a city and made a proposal for Bowling Green to establish more cultural and educational establishments, such as science, history, and art museums.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Housing and Affordability (8 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Rent Costs and Regulation**: Statements express concerns about high rent and suggest measures such as rent control to manage increasing rates.
* **Tenant Protections and Landlord Accountability**: Some statements advocate for enhanced tenant rights, landlord responsibility for property upkeep, and the establishment of a grievance system.
* **Affordable Housing Supply and Incentives**: A statement indicates a need for more quality affordable rental units and suggests making their development worthwhile for builders.
* **University-Adjacent Housing and Neighborhood Issues**: Statements address concerns specific to areas near WKU, including residential parking and student livability, with one statement proposing the elimination of Section 8 housing to improve conditions.
* **Specific Renter Needs**: One statement identifies a demand for more pet-friendly housing options for renters.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants discussed issues regarding rental housing, with some proposing stronger tenant and renters rights and landlord accountability for maintaining property conditions, citing the existence of many overpriced, dilapidated rentals. Another participant suggested the creation of a tenant/landlord grievance department offering legal assistance. Additionally, a participant proposed incentivizing builders to develop more quality affordable rental units for residents, as opposed to focusing on luxury units.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: While participants broadly supported addressing overpriced rentals and incentivizing the development of more affordable rental units, opinions differed regarding the specific proposal to enact rent control laws to stabilize rent increases.

subContents.title: #### Parks and Recreation (7 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Expansion and Enhancement of Park Facilities**: Statements propose the addition of new amenities such as indoor pools, kayak trails, and specialized bike courses, as well as improvements to existing features like bark parks.
* **Increased Accessibility and Availability of Parks and Amenities**: Suggestions in the statements include extending park operating hours, providing year-round access to certain facilities, improving general access points like those for rivers, and allocating dedicated usage times for specific groups or activities.
* **Emphasis on Health and Active Lifestyles**: Some statements highlight the role of parks and recreation in promoting healthier living and providing opportunities for physical activity and therapy.
* **Development of Trails and Courses for Specific Activities**: Several statements call for the creation or addition of dedicated infrastructure such as trails for kayaking, walking, and nature exploration, and courses for biking.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants proposed several recreational enhancements, including a kayak trail from Lampkin Park to Barren River with improved river access. Another participant requested year-round indoor public swimming pools for general use and therapy, without time restrictions due to special swim leagues, to encourage healthier lifestyles. Additionally, a participant suggested adding more walking and nature trails to sports-centric parks and proposed designated hours for walkers at Paul Walker Golf Course.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
